generated.html:
DATA JOURNALISM

New Yorkers Don’t Like Rats: How Often Do They Complain?

It’s said that rats have lived in New York since 1750s. City administrations has been aggressively trying to get rid of rats for centuries. Its not yet over. A public rat sight complaint data-set created in 2010 offers a glimpse of how New Yorkers complain about rats.

MUSINGUZI BLANSHE

Published December 10th, 2019

The data-set doesn’t tell a complete story of New York rat problem. It’s simply shows places where people are likely to pick up a phone, dial 311 and report a complaint. No research has been done as to why some people report rats more than other.

Actually, Jonathan Auerbach, a doctorate at Columbia University, in 2014 authored a paper which showed that there could be less rats in areas where most complaints come from. His paper won a competition sponsored by the 180-year-old Royal Statistical Society of London.

A department of public health and mental hygiene spokesperson says after a complaint is logged, “we send an inspector to perform an inspection at that address. Inspectors look for signs of rat activity, like burrows or rat droppings, and order the property owner to remediate the conditions we find.”

Following this initial inspection, the complaint is logged as “closed,” however a second inspection of the property is carried out to ensure its in compliance. “If rat activity is found on reinspection, we issue summonses and will often treat the property with our own extermination staff.”

There are two complaints from Brooklyn for almost every complaint that come from other boroughs, except Staten Island that represent a complaint per seven complaints.

This means more folk in Brooklyn complain about rats when data is zoomed in to zip code level. Unsurprisingly, a Brooklyn zip has the highest number of cumulative complaints since 2012.

The New York rat sight data-set has a category of complaints that comes from each zip code.

Where are the zip codes of New Yorkers who have been complaining of rats frequently or less frequently?

Less than 30 zip codes have reported less than 100 complaints since creation of rat sight data-set in 2010. They are wide-spread across the continent.

Most zip codes have reported in the range of below 1000 complaints. Almost all Queens and Staten Island zip codes fall in this category

There is no Staten Island zip code that has reported above 2000 complaints.

Only 12 zip codes have recorded complaints in the range of 3000 and 4000. Four of them are situated in Brooklyn, two in Bronx and four situated in Manhattan

Only one zip code 11221 situated in Brooklyn has ever recorded over 4000 complaints.

That's New York and its rat complaints per zip code.

Complaints peaked in all boroughs except Staten Island in 2017 and then started going down. Does this explain mean that people got tired of complaining or did city administration kill many rats, reducing its population?

A department of public health and mental hygiene spokesperson said they don’t measure rat population using this data set. But he claimed that places failing rat inspection standards, a measure they use to map areas likely to high number of rats show 60 percent reduction in inspection failures.

Compplaints Peaked In All Boroughs In 2017 Except Staten Island

In 2017, Mayor Bill de Blasio became the latest city leader to launch a war on city’s rats. He said that he wanted “more rat corpses,” as he unveiled a $32 million assault. But the department of public health said they don’t have statistics of rats they killed since launch of this program.

I published a details of this project on my Github account
